bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 2, 1917

div1.p: Gorgas describes to Kean further communication difficulties in constituting the Ambulance Corps in France.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 2, 1917
div1.opener:
Reed Dec 4
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
November 2,1917.
wcg-hhw
From Gen Gorgas
Colonel J. R. Kean, U.S. Army,
U.S. Army Ambulance Service,
With the French Army,
France.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
Yours of September 22d, enclosing letter of August
24th from Richard Norton, is acknowledged. Before you re-
ceive this letter you will have had letters from me which will
explain the status of the Ambulance Sections. You evidently
left the United States under an entire misapprehension as to what
this status is. A good many questions in your letter of Sept.
22d have already been answered in letters since written to you,
but for fear some may have been mislaid I will answer your ques-
tions in detail.

I do not see that it makes any difference to us how many
men in the old sections enlist in our service. It is some
advantage, of course, to have experienced men, but we can furnish
you with just as many men as you wish of the very highest order
of intelligence from Allentown. But I am so at sea here as to
what you are driving at, and you are so at sea as to what we
intend that I might evidently entirely misunderstand the whole
situation. The taking over of these American organizations from
the French is to be entirely voluntary on their part. If they
want to stay in the service of the French and the French want to
(Col. Kean, U.S.A.)
2.
keep them I would not urge them to come in; I don't see that
we need them in the least. I don't see why you need bother
at all about Mr. Norton; let him do exactly as he pleases.

So far everything you have asked for with regard to Sections
in France has been granted. Your present authorization for
taking over American Sections is 49. No cable has been
received from General Pershing asking for twenty Sections from
Allentown. A cable has been received asking for ten Sections
and 300 loose men. This has been ordered by the Chief of Staff
and the men are now awaiting transportation.

The French Legation is still begging us not to assign the
Allentown Sections to the various camps. They assure me that
General Pershing is in error as to the wishes of the French
Government - that their wishes are still the same as those ex-
pressed by General Joffre when he was here, namely, that we
should furnish the French Government with 169 Sections to be as-
signed to duty with the French Army. In this letter of yours
you are still under the impression that these Sections were for
use with our Army.

Your high officers who are Reserve Corps' men can be used
anywhere; those not M.D.'s who have been commissioned in the
Ambulance Section can only be used in that Section. I should
think you and Bradley could manage this between you by assigning
the M.D's. to other divisions. I want to conserve the M.D's. as
3.
(Col. J.R. Kean, U.S. Army)
much as possible and use non-M.D.'s wherever non-M.D.'s can be
advantageously substituted. I should think it advantageous
for you to commission the men who are with the Sections that you
take over from the French service and it is my intention to leave
the commissioning in all the Ambulance Sections under your juris-
diction to yourself when they get over there. I think the
commissioning should be as much as possible from the ranks of
the Ambulance Section itself. This Section, I think, is com-
posed of the very best material we have in the Army. It is the
intention of the Department to replace by fresh Sections any Sec-
tion that we may take away from the French Army as rapidly as such
separation takes place, the idea being that it is advantageous to
us to keep these trained Sections in France to be used by our Army
in case of emergency. I imagine that when you once get in the
swing and our Army supplied, it will not very often occur that we
take the French Sections.

Captain Boyle's present status in the office is that of
Captain in the Ambulance Section, to help out in anything that per-
tains to this Section. He has been cabling direct to Andrew, because
I thought in this way we could get an idea of what you all were driv-
ing at, but I see that things cannot be hastened in this way and
shall let the matter drop in order to try to get information through
official channels. So far as you and I are concerned the official
4.
cables have given me no information and have
apparently caused you nothing but trouble.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, W. C. Gorgas.
Surgeon General, U. S. Army.
